# Oris AI Dental Knowledge Base - Comprehensive Procedures Guide

## Preventive Dentistry

### Routine Dental Examination
**Duration:** 30-45 minutes  
**Recommended Frequency:** Every 6 months  
**What's Included:**
- Comprehensive oral health assessment
- Digital radiographs (X-rays) when necessary
- Oral cancer screening
- Gum disease evaluation
- Bite analysis
- Treatment planning consultation
- Oral hygiene education

**Benefits:**
- Early detection of dental issues
- Prevention of costly treatments
- Maintenance of optimal oral health
- Professional cleaning recommendations

### Professional Dental Cleaning (Prophylaxis)
**Duration:** 45-60 minutes  
**Recommended Frequency:** Every 6 months  
**Process:**
- Ultrasonic scaling to remove tartar
- Hand scaling for detailed cleaning
- Polishing to remove surface stains
- Fluoride treatment application
- Personalized oral hygiene instruction

**Benefits:**
- Removes plaque and tartar buildup
- Prevents gum disease
- Freshens breath
- Maintains healthy gums
- Reduces risk of cavities

### Deep Cleaning (Scaling and Root Planing)
**Duration:** 1-2 hours per quadrant  
**Indications:** Gum disease (periodontitis)  
**Process:**
- Local anesthesia for comfort
- Deep scaling below gum line
- Root surface smoothing
- Antimicrobial irrigation
- Post-treatment care instructions

**Recovery:**
- Mild discomfort for 24-48 hours
- Avoid hard foods initially
- Gentle oral hygiene
- Follow-up appointment in 4-6 weeks

## Restorative Dentistry

### Composite Fillings (White Fillings)
**Duration:** 30-90 minutes depending on size  
**Material:** Tooth-colored composite resin  
**Advantages:**
- Natural appearance
- Bonds directly to tooth
- Preserves more natural tooth structure
- Mercury-free option
- Immediate functionality

**Procedure:**
1. Local anesthesia application
2. Decay removal and tooth preparation
3. Bonding agent application
4. Composite placement in layers
5. Light curing for hardening
6. Shaping and polishing

**Aftercare:**
- Avoid eating for 2 hours
- Normal function after numbness wears off
- Good oral hygiene maintenance
- Regular dental checkups

### Dental Crowns
**Duration:** 2-3 appointments over 2-3 weeks  
**Types Available:**
- Porcelain (most natural appearance)
- Porcelain-fused-to-metal (strong and aesthetic)
- Gold (most durable)
- Zirconia (strong and natural-looking)

**Indications:**
- Large fillings that compromise tooth structure
- Root canal treated teeth
- Severely worn or broken teeth
- Cosmetic improvements
- Dental implant restorations

**Process:**
1. First visit: Tooth preparation and temporary crown
2. Laboratory fabrication (1-2 weeks)
3. Second visit: Permanent crown placement

### Root Canal Therapy
**Duration:** 1-3 appointments, 60-90 minutes each  
**Purpose:** Save infected or severely damaged teeth  
**Procedure:**
1. Local anesthesia and isolation
2. Access hole creation
3. Pulp and nerve tissue removal
4. Canal cleaning and shaping
5. Disinfection and filling
6. Temporary or permanent restoration

**Success Rate:** 85-97% depending on case complexity  
**Aftercare:**
- Mild discomfort for 2-3 days
- Avoid chewing on treated side initially
- Crown placement recommended for back teeth
- Regular follow-up appointments

## Cosmetic Dentistry

### Teeth Whitening
**Professional In-Office Whitening:**
- Duration: 60-90 minutes
- Results: 3-8 shades lighter
- Uses concentrated whitening gel
- Immediate results
- Custom mouth guard provided for touch-ups

**Take-Home Whitening:**
- Duration: 2-4 weeks of nightly use
- Custom-fitted trays
- Professional-grade whitening gel
- Gradual, natural-looking results
- More comfortable for sensitive teeth

**Maintenance:**
- Avoid staining foods/drinks for 48 hours post-treatment
- Regular touch-up treatments
- Good oral hygiene
- Professional cleanings

### Porcelain Veneers
**Duration:** 2-3 appointments over 2-3 weeks  
**Best For:**
- Chipped or worn teeth
- Discolored teeth resistant to whitening
- Gaps between teeth
- Slightly crooked teeth
- Uneven tooth sizes

**Process:**
1. Consultation and treatment planning
2.

Consultation and treatment planning
2. Tooth preparation (minimal enamel removal)
3. Temporary veneers placement
4. Laboratory fabrication
5. Final veneer bonding

**Longevity:** 10-20 years with proper care  
**Care Instructions:**
- Avoid biting hard objects
- Don't use teeth as tools
- Wear night guard if grinding
- Regular dental visits

### Dental Bonding
**Duration:** 30-60 minutes per tooth  
**Best For:**
- Small chips or cracks
- Minor gaps
- Discoloration
- Irregular tooth shapes
- Less expensive alternative to veneers

**Procedure:**
1. Tooth surface preparation
2. Bonding agent application
3. Composite resin placement
4. Sculpting and shaping
5. Light curing and polishing

**Maintenance:**
- Avoid staining substances
- Regular oral hygiene
- Professional cleanings
- Touch-ups as needed (5-10 years)

## Oral Surgery

### Tooth Extraction
**Simple Extraction:**
- Duration: 20-40 minutes
- Local anesthesia
- Immediate aftercare instructions
- Healing time: 1-2 weeks

**Surgical Extraction:**
- Duration: 45-90 minutes
- May require sedation
- Sutures placement
- Healing time: 2-4 weeks

**Post-Extraction Care:**
- Bite on gauze for 30-45 minutes
- Avoid rinsing for 24 hours
- Ice application for swelling
- Soft diet for 2-3 days
- Pain medication as prescribed

### Dental Implants
**Duration:** 3-9 months total treatment time  
**Success Rate:** 95-98%  
**Process:**
1. Initial consultation and planning
2. Implant placement surgery
3. Healing period (osseointegration): 3-6 months
4. Abutment placement
5. Crown fabrication and placement

**Benefits:**
- Permanent tooth replacement
- Preserves jawbone
- Natural appearance and function
- No impact on adjacent teeth
- Long-lasting solution (20+ years)

**Candidacy Requirements:**
- Adequate bone density
- Healthy gums
- Good oral hygiene
- Non-smoker (preferred)
- Realistic expectations

## Emergency Dental Care

### Dental Pain Management
**Immediate Steps:**
1. Rinse with warm salt water
2. Apply cold compress externally
3. Take over-the-counter pain relievers
4. Avoid hot/cold foods
5. Contact dental office immediately

**When to Seek Emergency Care:**
- Severe, persistent pain
- Facial swelling
- Fever accompanying dental pain
- Traumatic injury
- Knocked-out tooth
- Lost filling causing pain

### Knocked-Out Tooth (Avulsed Tooth)
**Immediate Action (First 30 minutes critical):**
1. Handle tooth by crown, not root
2. Rinse gently if dirty (don't scrub)
3. Try to reinsert in socket
4. If unable to reinsert, store in milk or saliva
5. Seek emergency dental care immediately

**Prognosis:**
- Best if reimplanted within 30 minutes
- Good success rate up to 2 hours
- Follow-up care essential

### Broken or Chipped Tooth
**Immediate Care:**
1. Save tooth fragments
2. Rinse mouth with warm water
3. Apply cold compress for swelling
4. Cover sharp edges with dental wax
5.

Handle tooth by crown, not root
2. Rinse gently if dirty (don't scrub)
3. Try to reinsert in socket
4. If unable to reinsert, store in milk or saliva
5. Seek emergency dental care immediately

**Prognosis:**
- Best if reimplanted within 30 minutes
- Good success rate up to 2 hours
- Follow-up care essential

### Broken or Chipped Tooth
**Immediate Care:**
1. Save tooth fragments
2. Rinse mouth with warm water
3. Apply cold compress for swelling
4. Cover sharp edges with dental wax
5. Schedule emergency appointment

**Treatment Options:**
- Small chips: Dental bonding
- Large chips: Crown or veneer
- Severe breaks: Root canal and crown
- Non-restorable: Extraction and replacement

## Pediatric Dentistry

### First Dental Visit
**Recommended Age:** By age 1 or within 6 months of first tooth  
**What to Expect:**
- Gentle examination
- Parent/caregiver education
- Fluoride application if appropriate
- Home care instructions
- Establishing dental home

### Preventive Treatments for Children
**Fluoride Treatments:**
- Applied every 6 months
- Strengthens tooth enamel
- Prevents cavities
- Safe and effective

**Dental Sealants:**
- Applied to back teeth
- Protects against cavities
- Typically done age 6-14
- Lasts 5-10 years

### Managing Dental Anxiety in Children
**Techniques:**
- Tell-show-do method
- Positive reinforcement
- Distraction techniques
- Nitrous oxide (laughing gas) if needed
- Creating positive associations

## Gum Disease Treatment

### Gingivitis
**Symptoms:**
- Red, swollen gums
- Bleeding during brushing/flossing
- Bad breath
- Tender gums

**Treatment:**
- Professional cleaning
- Improved oral hygiene
- Antimicrobial rinse
- Regular maintenance

### Periodontitis
**Symptoms:**
- All gingivitis symptoms plus:
- Gum recession
- Loose teeth
- Pus between teeth and gums
- Changes in bite

**Treatment:**
- Scaling and root planing
- Antibiotic therapy
- Surgical intervention if severe
- Ongoing maintenance therapy

**Maintenance:**
- Professional cleanings every 3-4 months
- Excellent home care
- Regular monitoring
- Lifestyle modifications

## Oral Health Tips

### Daily Oral Hygiene
**Essential Steps:**
1. Brush twice daily with fluoride toothpaste
2. Floss daily
3. Use antimicrobial mouthwash
4. Clean tongue
5. Stay hydrated

**Proper Brushing Technique:**
- Use soft-bristled toothbrush
- 45-degree angle to gums
- Gentle circular motions
- Brush for 2 minutes
- Replace toothbrush every 3 months

### Diet and Oral Health
**Foods to Limit:**
- Sugary snacks and drinks
- Acidic foods and beverages
- Sticky candies
- Hard foods that can crack teeth

**Teeth-Friendly Foods:**
- Dairy products (calcium)
- Leafy greens
- Lean proteins
- Fruits and vegetables
- Water (especially fluoridated)

### Lifestyle Factors
**Habits to Avoid:**
- Smoking and tobacco use
- Excessive alcohol consumption
- Using teeth as tools
- Teeth grinding (seek treatment)
- Poor oral hygiene

**Positive Habits:**
- Regular dental visits
- Consistent oral hygiene
- Healthy diet
- Wearing mouthguards during sports
- Managing stress

This comprehensive guide provides evidence-based information for dental education and patient consultation. Always recommend professional examination for accurate diagnosis and personalized treatment planning.

# Oris AI Dental Emergency Guide

## Dental Emergencies Classification

### URGENT - Seek Immediate Care (Within 1 Hour)

#### Severe Dental Pain
**Symptoms:**
- Throbbing, intense pain
- Pain that prevents sleep
- Pain radiating to ear, jaw, or neck
- Swelling of face or jaw
- Fever accompanying dental pain

**Immediate Actions:**
1. Rinse with warm salt water
2. Take prescribed or over-the-counter pain medication
3. Apply cold compress to outside of face (20 minutes on, 20 off)
4. Avoid hot or cold foods/drinks
5. Contact emergency dental service immediately

**Do NOT:**
- Place aspirin directly on tooth or gums
- Apply heat to the affected area
- Ignore signs of infection (fever, swelling)

#### Knocked-Out Tooth (Dental Avulsion)
**Time Sensitive - Success depends on quick action**

**Immediate Steps:**
1. Find the tooth and pick it up by the crown (white part)
2. Do NOT touch the root
3. If dirty, rinse gently with water for 10 seconds maximum
4. Try to reinsert the tooth immediately:
   - Hold tooth by crown
   - Place in socket
   - Bite down gently on clean cloth

**If Cannot Reinsert:**
- Place tooth in milk (best option)
- Alternatives: Patient's saliva, saline solution
- Do NOT store in water
- Do NOT let tooth dry out

**Get to dentist within 30 minutes for best outcome**

#### Dental Trauma with Bleeding
**Symptoms:**
- Profuse bleeding from mouth
- Visible broken or displaced teeth
- Jaw pain or inability to close mouth normally
- Facial swelling or bruising

**Immediate Care:**
1. Control bleeding with clean gauze (bite down firmly)
2. Apply cold compress to reduce swelling
3. Save any tooth fragments
4. Seek immediate emergency care
5. If jaw injury suspected, go to hospital emergency room

#### Severe Infection/Abscess
**Warning Signs:**
- Severe facial swelling
- Difficulty swallowing
- Difficulty breathing
- High fever (over 101°F)
- Swollen lymph nodes

**Immediate Actions:**
1. Contact emergency dental service
2. If breathing difficulty, call 911
3. Take prescribed antibiotics if available
4. Use cold compress for swelling
5. Stay hydrated

### SEMI-URGENT - Seek Care Within 24 Hours

#### Broken or Chipped Tooth
**Assessment:**
- Large chip with pain: More urgent
- Small chip without pain: Less urgent
- Sharp edges cutting tongue/cheek: Needs attention

**Immediate Care:**
1. Save tooth pieces if possible
2. Rinse mouth with warm water
3. Cover sharp edges with dental wax or sugarless gum
4. Use cold compress if swelling
5. Take pain medication if needed

#### Lost Filling or Crown
**Symptoms:**
- Sensitivity to temperature
- Discomfort when chewing
- Visible hole in tooth

**Temporary Measures:**
1. Keep area clean
2. Use temporary dental cement (pharmacy)
3. Avoid chewing on affected side
4. For lost crown: Try to place back with denture adhesive
5. Schedule dental appointment within 24-48 hours

#### Moderate Dental Pain
**Characteristics:**
- Persistent but manageable pain
- Sensitivity to hot/cold
- Pain when chewing

**Management:**
1. Over-the-counter pain relievers
2. Warm salt water rinses
3. Avoid trigger foods/drinks
4. Keep area clean
5. Schedule appointment within 24 hours

### NON-URGENT - Schedule Appointment Within Week

#### Minor Tooth Sensitivity
**Symptoms:**
- Brief pain with hot/cold foods
- No constant pain
- No swelling

**Self-Care:**
1. Use desensitizing toothpaste
2. Avoid extreme temperatures
3. Gentle brushing with soft toothbrush
4. Schedule routine appointment

#### Small Food Particle Stuck
**Safe Removal Methods:**
1. Gentle flossing
2. Water irrigation
3.

Over-the-counter pain relievers
2. Warm salt water rinses
3. Avoid trigger foods/drinks
4. Keep area clean
5. Schedule appointment within 24 hours

### NON-URGENT - Schedule Appointment Within Week

#### Minor Tooth Sensitivity
**Symptoms:**
- Brief pain with hot/cold foods
- No constant pain
- No swelling

**Self-Care:**
1. Use desensitizing toothpaste
2. Avoid extreme temperatures
3. Gentle brushing with soft toothbrush
4. Schedule routine appointment

#### Small Food Particle Stuck
**Safe Removal Methods:**
1. Gentle flossing
2. Water irrigation
3. Toothpick (very carefully)

**Do NOT Use:**
- Sharp metal objects
- Excessive force
- Anything that could push object deeper

## Emergency Pain Management

### Over-the-Counter Medications
**For Adults:**
- Ibuprofen: 400-600mg every 6-8 hours (maximum 2400mg/day)
- Acetaminophen: 500-1000mg every 6-8 hours (maximum 3000mg/day)
- Can alternate ibuprofen and acetaminophen for severe pain

**For Children:**
- Follow age-appropriate dosing on package
- Consult pediatrician if unsure
- Avoid aspirin in children under 18

### Natural Pain Relief Methods
**Cold Therapy:**
- Ice pack on outside of cheek
- 20 minutes on, 20 minutes off
- Reduces swelling and numbs pain

**Salt Water Rinse:**
- 1/2 teaspoon salt in 8 oz warm water
- Gentle swishing, don't swallow
- Helps reduce bacteria and inflammation

**Clove Oil:**
- Natural numbing agent
- Apply small amount to cotton swab
- Dab on affected tooth
- Use sparingly - can be irritating

## Preventing Dental Emergencies

### Protective Measures
**Sports Activities:**
- Wear custom-fitted mouthguard
- Especially important for contact sports
- Replace mouthguard annually

**Daily Habits:**
- Don't use teeth as tools
- Avoid chewing ice, hard candies, popcorn kernels
- Don't bite non-food objects (pens, fingernails)
- Cut hard foods into smaller pieces

### Regular Dental Care
**Preventive Appointments:**
- Regular cleanings and checkups
- Address small problems before they become emergencies
- Professional assessment of oral health

**Home Care:**
- Brush twice daily with fluoride toothpaste
- Daily flossing
- Use mouthwash
- Replace toothbrush every 3 months

## Emergency Dental Kit

### Essential Items to Keep at Home
1. **Contact Information:**
   - Emergency dental number
   - Regular dentist contact
   - Local hospital emergency room

2. **Medications:**
   - Ibuprofen and acetaminophen
   - Temporary dental cement
   - Clove oil

3. **Supplies:**
   - Gauze pads
   - Cold compress
   - Small container with lid
   - Dental wax
   - Salt
   - Dental floss

4. **Instructions:**
   - Emergency procedure guide
   - Medication dosing information

## When to Go to Hospital Emergency Room

### Dental Injuries Requiring ER Care
- Jaw fracture or dislocation
- Severe facial trauma
- Uncontrolled bleeding
- Difficulty breathing or swallowing
- Signs of serious infection with fever
- Loss of consciousness from dental trauma

### What ER Can and Cannot Do
**ER Can Provide:**
- Pain medication
- Antibiotics for infection
- Treatment for trauma and bleeding
- X-rays for jaw fractures

**ER Cannot Provide:**
- Definitive dental treatment
- Root canals or fillings
- Tooth reimplantation
- Complex dental procedures

**Follow-up dental care will still be necessary**

## Post-Emergency Care

### After Emergency Treatment
1. Follow all dentist instructions carefully
2. Take prescribed medications as directed
3. Apply ice as recommended
4. Eat soft foods
5. Avoid smoking and alcohol
6.

Follow all dentist instructions carefully
2. Take prescribed medications as directed
3. Apply ice as recommended
4. Eat soft foods
5. Avoid smoking and alcohol
6. Schedule follow-up appointment

### Signs of Complications
**Contact dentist if you experience:**
- Increasing pain after 2-3 days
- Persistent bleeding
- New or worsening swelling
- Fever
- Allergic reaction to medications
- Foul taste or odor

### Recovery Expectations
**Normal After Emergency Treatment:**
- Mild to moderate discomfort for 2-3 days
- Some swelling for 24-48 hours
- Slight bleeding for a few hours
- Sensitivity to temperature

**Not Normal - Contact Dentist:**
- Severe pain increasing after treatment
- Excessive bleeding
- Signs of infection
- Numbness lasting more than 4 hours

## Special Considerations

### Pregnant Patients
- Most dental emergencies can be safely treated
- Inform dentist of pregnancy
- Some medications may be limited
- X-rays with protective shielding are safe

### Patients with Medical Conditions
**Heart Conditions:**
- May need antibiotic premedication
- Inform dentist of all heart medications

**Diabetes:**
- Dental infections can affect blood sugar
- Monitor glucose levels closely
- Healing may take longer

**Blood Thinners:**
- Increased bleeding risk
- Don't stop medications without physician approval
- Inform dentist of all blood-thinning medications

### Children's Dental Emergencies
**Special Considerations:**
- Children may not accurately describe pain
- Look for behavioral changes
- Baby teeth that are knocked out are not reimplanted
- Permanent teeth need immediate attention

**Calming Techniques:**
- Stay calm yourself
- Explain procedures simply
- Offer comfort items
- Praise cooperation

Remember: While this guide provides helpful information for dental emergencies, it does not replace professional dental care. When in doubt, always contact a dental professional or seek emergency care.

## Warranty and Guarantee Information

### Treatment Warranties
**Restorative Work:**
- Crowns and bridges: 2 years
- Fillings: 1 year
- Root canals: 2 years
- Implants: 10 years (implant only)

**Cosmetic Work:**
- Veneers: 2 years
- Bonding: 1 year
- Whitening: Results not guaranteed (varies by individual)

### Warranty Conditions
**Coverage Includes:**
- Defects in materials or workmanship
- Premature failure under normal use
- Replacement or repair at no charge

**Warranty Requirements:**
- Regular maintenance appointments
- Good oral hygiene
- No damage from trauma or neglect
- Compliance with post-treatment instructions
